This particular team got it, probably because caring about others is in their DNA. It's not in everyone's, and even if it's in yours it can be easy to forget thanks to your own battles. That's OK. But do think about those who are worried sick right now. They need you. 6/6

Does an employer do this? Of course not. THEY ARE NOT YOUR FAMILY. And they don't want you to realize this. They just want you to behave like they are, without reciprocity. (12/12)
If your family had a yacht, they'd share it with you. If they knew you were struggling to make ends meet, they'd help you. (11/x)

Your employer wants you to work longer hours without pay and to not fight for higher wages or better benefits because "family members support each other!" Meanwhile the owners take home the profits and enjoy their yachts while you eat ramen and struggle with bills. (10/x)

It should be clear now that the entire "we're a family!" narrative is very one-directional. What your employer wants from you is the *loyalty you would give your family* without returning the same. They're appealing to your need to belong. (9/x)

Imagine falling ill, and you're sick enough you can't really work but not so sick that you're incapacitated. A family would feed you, tell you to rest, and to just worry about your health. Your employer will deduct sick days and past that you're unpaid. You may get fired. (8/x)

Imagine someone you love dies. Your family will give you room to grieve. They'll support you. They'll share your pain in hopes of diminishing it. Your employer might give you a couple of days off for bereavement leave. Extra time off *you need to grieve* will be unpaid. (7/x)
What do families do? (Or, what are they supposed to do?) They support you, love you, care for you while you are ill or hurting. They provide a safe retreat and protect you. We all need this. (6/x)

Don't get me wrong. Flex time, free food, solid benefits are all good to have, and they are likely to help keep one's employees happy. But they do NOT validate the BS narrative that the company is "family". (5/x)

So what many companies will do is start a narrative that the workplace is your "second home" and your workmates are "your family". And they may even toss in a few superficial bonuses to shore up the narrative, like free food, flex time, etc. (4/x)

The thing is, every time someone resigns to go elsewhere, it costs companies $$ to recruit, select and onboard. There's almost always a ramping-up period for the new hire to learn the ropes. That cuts into profits. (3/x)

What are the expectations in employment today? 1: You, the employee, provide labour in exchange for wages, paid by the employer. 2: You *may* at any time leave the organization for greener pastures. Note that I wrote *may* and not *can*. Most of us are coerced into jobs. (2/x)
"We're not a company, we're a family!" is one of the most foul, manipulative lies that can be told (and re-told) by organizational leadership. ğŸ‘‡ (1/x)
